text: Good afternoon everyone. Thanks for
coming along for the last session of
today. It's great to be here at Unreal
Fest in Orlando. Nice to be in the
sunshine state where it hasn't stopped
raining for three days. So that's been
lovely. For those of you that don't know
me, my name is Jack Gullen. I'm a senior
visualization specialist at McLaren. I
work in our design team and I work on a
day-to-day basis working on our future
cars. Um, like I say, it's great to be
here. It's been a great festival so far,
seeing all the latest developments
that's been going on. Um, what I do and
what the team I work in do is basically
we helped create the designer visions
into reality. A lot of that is based
around Unreal. So, a lot of the stuff we
do is some still imagery, some cinematic
renders, and then we get involved like
things like virtual reality, car
configurators, and like I say, a lot of
that is done in Unreal among other
things. But, um, it's great to kind of
get up here and talk about what we do.
Most of what we do in the design studio
tends to be confidential. So, it's nice
to be able to show you some of the stuff
we work on. Um, like I said, today we're
going to do things a little bit
differently. Normally, we stand up here,
we show some videos, we show some
images, and we talk around the current
cars. We're still going to do that, but
we're actually going to cover some of
the prototype stuff that we get onto in
the design studio. So, we're going to
focus on stuff that we actually tried
out one afternoon as an interesting
little idea. Basically, some procedural
worlds that we've worked on to basically
help push on our visualization content.
So, like I say, I'm lucky enough to be
working for McLaren. I work at our
McLaren Technology Center or MTC. This
isn't an AI image. We didn't ask Chat
GPT to make us some new super villain
layer. This is actually where I get to
work 5 days a week. Um, and it's great
here across not only here and our other
sites working with teams such as not
only design, HMI, our ergonomics teams,
our aerodynamics guys, and various other
departments. Um, using lots of different
technology and really all coming
together to make new supercars. Now,
what's great about that is Unreal is
actually intertwined with a lot of
different areas in the business. Like I
say, today we're going to focus on some
of the ways we use it in the design
studio.
One of the other nice things about our
office is we have our incredible
boulevard. Um, it's great source of
inspiration,
great source for visualization as well.
There's only this place in the world
where you can see a McLaren F1, a P1,
and a W1 all sitting alongside each
other. We're basically seeing
award-winning cars that are all there
that we can use as references for viz.
And they're also some of the fastest
cars in the world, some of the most
expensive cars in the world, but also
some of the rarest things that you can
find. We're incredibly fortunate at
McLaren to have an incredible color,
material, and finish team. They give us
lots of interesting samples and really
work with us to help push on our
visualization. That's a great thing to
be a part of, and but there's nothing
better than actually being able to get
down and see the cars themselves. and
that's a great source of inspiration for
us.
As we move further down the boulevard,
we're really lucky to share the space
with our Formula 1 team and it's great
to see them doing so well lately. Um,
one of the things you can see here, we
have our McLaren 750S and our McLaren
Artura sporting our livery that we
created at the end of last year and
Unreal really helped us deliver that
quickly. We had to create lots of
different imagery of the cars so that
the designers could create this livery
and then we could launch it. And like I
say, Unreal really helped speed up that
process for our rendering. Um, as I
mentioned, having the McLaren F1 team do
so well recently has been great. The
last time they won a constructor's
championship was 1998 when Unreal Engine
1 just launched. So, it's been a bit of
a while and hopefully it's not as long
before the next one. And it's good to
see the season starting so strong. So
hopefully we'll see some more trophies
on the Boulevard soon.
But as I mentioned, we're obviously here
to talk about Unreal Engine and how we
use it as part of the design studio.
We've been using it for over a decade.
Um, we use it for various different
things. Um, one of the things that we
use it for is obviously virtual reality.
So when the designers have a new sketch
and we have some test data, we can drop
it into a VR environment. We can walk
around the car. We can see it in
different scenarios, see in different
lighting conditions. And we do that on a
daily basis so that we can evaluate new
concepts. To support that, we also have
our car configurators. These are in real
time. You might have seen on our
website, we have our configurator. We
have a slightly different one for the
design team based inhouse. And what we
do here is we add functionality and we
add things at the request of the
designers that they need to be able to
evaluate things more clearly. And that
then lets them look at different data
sets, swap out different things,
different wheels, different materials,
different assets. Live basically lets
them evaluate things as quickly as
possible. And we also have our McLaren
special operations team and they do a
lot of bespoke content. They do our
customer liies and the guys over at MSO
also have their own configurator and
it's great that all these parts of the
business can work together for our
designs. Now the last thing we look at
is our research and development. So as
part of the viz team we're obviously
always trying to experiment with new
ways we can influence the design
process. So we work on lots of different
things. Some of the recent things we've
looked at with Unreal are megalytes,
substrate materials and we've looked at
metahumans a bit as well and even some
of the things we saw announced at the
state of Unreal yesterday. So, for
example, nanite foliage is going to be
incredibly useful for us and we look
forward to getting our hands on that.
And with that in mind, um, essentially
what we're going to talk about today is
procedural content generation. Now, PCG
has been around in Unreal for a while.
Some of you might have used it, some of
you might have not. Um, what it allows
us to do is essentially with only a
couple of assets, create vast amounts of
environments. One of the main challenges
of visualization, as some of you may
know, if you work in the automotive
sector, is that if you're trying to make
a perfect scene, it can take weeks or if
not months to create assets from
scratch. If you want to get things
absolutely perfect. Now, sometimes we
need a way to evaluate a design in a
couple of hours, and we want to be able
to basically show it in a million
different variations as possible. PCG is
one way we can do that. So, today we're
going to talk about that and just see
how we can basically do more with less.
So, one thing I should note, we're going
to start this because some of you in the
room may have not be new to viz. You may
be new to the automotive sector. So,
we're going to start this from the
ground up. So, we're very much going to
show this from a beginner standpoint.
So, some of you may be familiar with
this, but we wanted to make it so that
everyone here can understand what's
going on. So, we're going to do a brief
introduction to procedural content. From
there, we're then going to take our
McLaren W1 model and prep it for
animation. So, we'll get it ready in a
control rig in UE 5.5. And then lastly,
we'll bring it all together for PCG in
Automotive Viz. and we'll show you how
it can not only influence our car
configurator, but our animations as
well.
So, like I say, the two main things
we're going to start with today, we're
going to build a basic PCG volume. We'll
just set up a couple standard different
forest environments so that you're good
to go with our scene. And then we'll
animate our W1 model and we'll have it
set up for our level sequences. So, then
we can build upon this and create some
new content.
So, we'll start completely from the
beginning, complete empty project, and
we'll show you how we can make some
standard PCG volumes. We'll go through
this quite quickly for those of you that
are familiar, just so you can guys get
up to speed as well. So, we've got a
complete empty scene here. All we have
is a basic landscape, grass material,
and we're going to create a new PCG
graph. And we'll open this up,
and we'll very quickly just make our
standard scene. So, we're going to grab
a landscape data node. So, we need to
access the landscape in the scene and
then we're going to access our surface
sampler. Now, we get these two things so
that we can tell the landscape how much
content we want to spawn in a certain
area. And then from here, we can
actually dial this up up and down so we
can control how much content spawns in
those volumes. We can also use a
transform points node. This allowed us
to give a little bit of variation to
what's going on. So, we can actually
vary the assets that are spawning. So we
can spawn 3D models in different
rotations, different scales, different
positions, and basically do more with
less here. Just from this one simple
node, we can spawn lots of random
content.
And lastly, we need our static mesh
spawner. And this is where we basically
tell it what 3D content we want to spawn
in the scene.
Once we have that set up, that is our
basic setup. So I'll just recap that
very quickly so you can see it on one
slide. Super nice and simple. We're
accessing our landscape data. We're
getting our surface sampler node. Once
we have that, we can control how much
content is in the basically the volume.
We can then access our transform points
node. This lets us vary the content in
the scene. And then lastly, we have our
static mesh spawner where we can spawn
in our content itself. So, let's go back
and do that just now. So, jumping back
here, we have our static mesh spawner.
And then we're just going to add two new
array elements. All we're going to do
here is drop in two tree models. We've
got these from the Fab Marketplace.
They're free assets, so anyone can use
them. So, we're just going to drag and
drop these in so that we're ready to
create our volume in the scene.
Now, once we we've done that, we can
then save this and then bring it back
into our environment.
So, we'll just grab this here and then
we're good to go.
So again, we'll just save this and then
we're just going to minimize this here.
We'll just drag and drop our PCG graph
we've just created. And now we have a
random volume and we can change the seed
value on the right hand side here and
essentially vary our content as much as
we want just by changing that number
value. Just like video games, if you
played Minecraft, you get a different
seed, you get a different world. Same
procedure here. Um, we've got a bit much
content here. So, we're just going to
knock back how much is spawning per
square meter so we can see a little bit
more of what's going on.
We'll probably reduce that a little bit
further just so we can see it a little
more clearly.
Cool. So, we have our basic volume here.
Nice and simple. Nothing too complex.
We'll now just drag and drop one in we
made earlier. So, all we've done here is
dialed it up a little bit more. We've
added in four or five different tree
models, some rocks, some ground debris,
and all we've done is basically built on
what we previously had. So, we've just
taken our blueprints, duplicated some of
these, and plugged in some more
variables, change the 3D content, and
this lets us just basically vary the
scene a lot more. Gives us a little bit
more control over what's going on.
So, just to have a quick look at that,
all we've done is we've duplicated um
our surface sampler mode and then our
static mesh spawner. By using these, we
can then change out the assets. So, we
can control the rocks, we can control
the ground debris. We don't have to use
transform points every time. It's just a
little bit handy if you want to have a
bit more control. But that's really all
there is to it to a basic standard PCG
volume. Now, you can add a lot more
content here. There's been tons of
sessions across Unreal Fest and there's
lots of resources online how you can do
more, but we're going to come back to
this in a second, but essentially for
now, we've got our volume, we've got our
landscape, and everything's set up and
good to go. So, we've just duplicated
our assets out 15 or 16 times and we've
got our forest environment that we can
then use in our scene.
One thing to note, obviously this
content is procedural. It's constantly
changing. We can randomize it as much as
we want. But what if we find something
we really like and we want to save it
because the PCG stuff can be quite
processor intensive. So, what you can
actually do is if you basically select
all the volumes in the scene, you can
then come down here and select our clear
PCG link button and this will convert it
all to actors. And that means it's not
going to randomize anymore. So if you've
got an environment you really like, you
can then save this, keep it. When you
reload the level, everything's good to
go. Now, for today, I mentioned this is
for our configurator where we want to do
random environments. So we're going to
keep everything procedural, but just
wanted to show you as an aside exactly
how we can do that.
So we'll come back to that in a second,
but we've got our environment. Now we
need a car model. So, what we're going
to use today is our McLaren W1. This is
our latest ultimate series supercar. And
this is the successor to the F1 and the
P1. And the W1's been a great car to be
a part of, and it's been great to see
all the reception to that being
launched. So, what we're going to do is
we're again, we're just going to drop
this into a blank scene.
So, we have our standard base model
here. We've just dragged and dropped our
FBX. Everything's been combined exactly
as we need it for animation. We've got
it ready to go. And then, we just need
to add some materials.
So, we have our materials set up and
ready to go here. We've just dragged and
dropped these in. Um, for those of you
who are not familiar, many of you will
be. Um, Epic do provide an automotive
material pack. It's probably the best
resource for getting started with
visualization for cars. There is so much
content in there. There's tons of body
paints, caliper paints, tire materials,
carbon fibers, metals, plastics,
interior materials that you will need.
Really, if you're new to this business,
100% recommend checking that out. We've
essentially used that for quickness. And
also we have some bespoke McLaren
materials as well. So now once we've
applied all our materials and things are
looking good, we essentially now need to
get this ready for animation. So we have
this set up as a skeletal mesh. And what
I mean by that is we basically have
bones assigned to the geometry so that
we can manipulate the car as we need to.
So we can click on the main body, we can
click on each of the wheels, and you can
see the pivots moving as I jump around
the model here. And this means we have
control over different parts. You can
see we can rotate the wheels. The
calipers are moving here, but we'll
correct this when we convert it into a
control rig. But it means we have the
main points of the car, only the five
things we need, four wheels, and the
main body allows us to do a standard
animation. And it's great that now you
can do this all in the editor itself.
You don't need to do it in third party
software. You might have a preference,
but if you want to do everything in
UEIE, you are entirely able to do so.
Now, you may also want to essentially do
more there. You may want to add some
more to the skeleton itself.
What we can do is actually we can jump
into our skeleton and edit it. This may
be useful if you want to add more parts.
You might want to animate some doors
opening for example. You might want to
animate the rear wing deploying. And we
can do all that just by right clicking
and adding a new bone in there. Now for
now we're going to keep this simple. So
we're going to keep it as the just the
main body itself and then the four
wheels. But if you were to add something
new, you need to make sure the geometry
is paired to it. So each of these bones
has polygons assigned to it. You can
view this if you go into the edit
weights um setting. Now if we jump in
here, we can see the wireframe itself
and then we can cons select the
different parts of the car and make sure
the correct content is selected. So we
have the main body, all the polygons are
there and then we also have the wheel
itself and we can jump around and make
sure that's all set. One thing I would
recommend, um this side of the editor is
quite heavy. Um this model here is
probably about 20 to 30 million
polygons. that runs incredibly slowly,
probably takes all night to convert. Um,
so if you're new to this, maybe use
either a decimated model, something more
low poly to get to grips with it. Trying
to select a single vertex in here, very
difficult, takes a long time, can really
get quite frustrating. But once it's set
up, we essentially have everything good
to go.
Once we've done that, we can now convert
it to a modular control rig. Now, there
are kind of two ways you can do this
right now. Um, there is you can either
use some nice third party plugins to
keep things nice and simple. It can
basically take a skeletal mesh and
convert it into Unreal's new control rig
system. Or you can do this all in
blueprints. Now, the blueprint process
takes around 40 50 minutes alone, so
we're not going to show all that today,
but we're going to post a follow-up blog
post on Unreal's developer site on how
we've done that exactly. But for now,
we've basically used a plugin that will
convert this. You might as well keep it
simple if you're trying to save time.
And this means our control rig is set
up. We have our wheels spinning
correctly. We have things moving when we
need them to. Um, we also have a bit
more control over the suspension if we
wanted to do that. But for now, we're
good and we're ready to animate.
Okay, so we now have our car model and
we have our procedural environment. We
need to tie this all together. So
basically, we want to show you how we
can use this not only for animation but
for our configurator as well. So,
jumping back to our forest scene, we've
now added in a standard road. We've just
used a Fab asset for an American road
texture. Nice material that we drop into
the scene on a plane. And then we need
to jump into a nice camera angle. We've
set this so that when we load in our car
model, we can see the car in the correct
kind of front three/arter view, but also
have so we have enough view of the
environment in the background because
that's the main thing that we're going
to be changing. So, we need to be able
to see that and how it affects the car.
So, we'll drop our car model in here and
we've hooked it up to a level sequencer.
Now, all we've done is just driven this
straight down the road so that you've
got a nice simple animation. Um, but
right now, if we want to change the
environment in the background, we have
to click on every single volume and
change the seed value manually. That's
quite an involved process. We obviously
don't want to have to do that every
single time. So, we could tie this up to
an event so that whenever the animation
sequence loops around, it calls an event
and it refreshes the content. But that's
going to be kind of difficult because if
you're trying to render this out in real
time, you don't want to see trees
turning on and off. That makes things a
little bit more difficult. So, we
decided to tie this up to our variant
manager, which we'll use for our car
configurator. So, we're going to show
you how we've done that now.
So, just jumping back out for a second,
we now need to create a new blueprint
class, which will have a custom event,
and we'll show you how we have our
randomization functionality.
So what we're going to do here, we'll
create a new blueprint. We'll jump in
and we'll basically do the functionality
as I said.
So once we've opened this up, we just
need to add a new custom event. So if we
recclick, sorry, if we right click, add
custom event, we'll give this a suitable
name and we'll just zoom in slightly.
One thing to note, um, we need to set
this to be able to be called in the
editor. If not, it's only going to just
work in a standard build. And by ticking
call editor, it means we can test it um
as much as we'd like. Um if not, things
aren't going to work here. So we'll make
sure that's ticked and then we'll work
on our actual custom event.
So we're going to right click here and
what we need to do is access all the
volumes in the scene. So we're going to
get all our PCG content just by
searching for PCG volume. And then we
need to grab each and every one and give
it a random number so that it randomizes
over time.
So, we're just going to loop through
every single one. We'll tie it up to the
array and then we'll get each of our
individual PCG actors. Now, before we
generate new content, we need to clean
up what's there before. So, we're just
going to search for a cleanup node here.
And once we've done that, we have our
target that we can access. Now, as I
said before, changing the number of the
seed value changes the random content
that's going on.
So we'll just set our seed here. So what
we want to do is we're going to give it
a random number. We're just going to
give it a random integer between zero
and a th00and. That should give us
enough variation so that we're never
going to see the same environment twice.
We've got 16 different volumes and a
thousand different possibilities for
each one. Very unlikely we're going to
see the same forest each time.
So, we'll just tie this up here. Don't
judge me on how clean my blueprints are.
And we definitely just not tidied this
up too much, but we're keeping it quite
simple. Um, essentially, now that we've
hooked all that up, the last thing we
need to do is just generate our new
random content. So, we'll add in our
generate node here.
And once we've gone done that, we'll set
things up. We'll save it, and we're
ready to go.
So we'll just compile and save this to
take a little bit of a closer look at
that. And this is the PCG graph we have
ourselves. So we have a new custom
event. We're going to get all the actors
in the scene. So basically all the

And then we'll basically generate our

One thing to bear in mind if you're

your content can be accessed by your

in the scene can essentially they are
set to generate on load. So, they're not
going to be accessed by your blueprint.
So, we need to make sure they're set to
generate on demand in the details panel.
Once we have that set, we are then ready
to tie things to our variant manager.
So, what we'll do now, we've just

We'll drag and drop that into our scene.
Now, once we have this, we can open our

So, all we need to do here is we're

And that's going to open up a window for

So, all we need to do here is once again

and we're just going to search for our

Now, having a nice little forest

See the car in a different light very

And then one other thing we can do is we
can swap out our assets. Now what's nice
is this is the exact same car, the exact

road. We haven't changed a thing. All
we've changed is that random volume in

different 3D geometry. So, we've just

different options for evaluating the car
within
Now once we developed all that we were
super excited about it. We showed it to
our designers. We thought this would be
something really useful for the
configurator. But we got quite excited
about the possibilities of procedural
content and we thought how much further
can we take this? So one of the things
we thought was well we now have infinite
landscapes that we can then build things
upon and we thought why not start
simulating real world environments even
though we're doing things random. The
real world can be random at times, but
why don't we take real world
environments and see how PCG can help
generate these? So, essentially what we
did was you can see here for those of
you familiar with racing, this is ORE
from Spa in Belgium. And the reason
we've chosen this is for various
different reasons. Um, one as a McLaren

two things are both important when we're
evaluating designs of our supercars. And
we basically wanted an environment that
we could use our PCG content on. So most
modern race tracks can either be street
circuits or lots of buildings going on.
Whereas the nice thing in this Belgian
track is that we have essentially apart
from a couple grandstands, the track is
just in the middle of the woods. It's
got a forest and we can use the existing
content we've built. Like I say, when
we're doing visualization, things can
take weeks or months to get complete
accuracy. If we wanted to get this track
completely correct, we would have to
either fly out there and scan it
ourselves or get lots of visual
references, and that would take a vast
amount of time. But if we're trying to
evaluate a car design in a couple of
hours, we can use some PCG content and
some procedural road generation to
basically try that out. So, this isn't
supposed to be world's most boring game
of spot the difference. What we've done
here is taken the L, sorry, the track
layout for Spa and then we've converted
that into Unreal Engine. All we've done
is just copied in an image of the track
itself, put a bit of transparency on it

our splines around manually. So I
basically took this in and trace some
spline cars, sorry, some splines around
the circuit itself.
We didn't have access to the height data
for SPA, so we didn't have access to a

is something we're just trying to do
quickly for some quick design reviews.
So all we did was we watched a kind of
point of view lap of someone driving
around Spa Franc.
So see the high points of the track, see
the the low points, see where some of
the turns were, and see how steep some
of the corners were. By doing all of
that, we can get a rough idea of the
track layout.
We can then basically use our spline and
trace around the inside of the circuit.
What's nice about that is once we've
done that, we can load in our PCG

racetrack with everything generating in
the middle. It's a little bit difficult
to see here, but what it's also doing

And like I say, this is still work in

We can basically get the designers
